net.openhft.chronicle.network.internal.netty

Class NioEventLoop

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.concurrent.AbstractExecutorService
      • io.netty.util.concurrent.AbstractEventExecutor
        • io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor
          • io.netty.channel.SingleThreadEventLoop
            • net.openhft.chronicle.network.internal.netty.NioEventLoop
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    io.netty.channel.EventLoop, io.netty.channel.EventLoopGroup, io.netty.util.concurrent.EventExecutor, io.netty.util.concurrent.EventExecutorGroup, Iterable<io.netty.util.concurrent.EventExecutor>, Executor, ExecutorService, ScheduledExecutorService

    public final class NioEventLoop
extends io.netty.channel.SingleThreadEventLoop
    SingleThreadEventLoop implementation which register the Channel's to a Selector and so does the multi-plexing of these in the event loop.

    • Method Detail

      • newTaskQueue

        protected Queue<Runnable> newTaskQueue()
        Overrides:
        newTaskQueue in class io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor

      • register

        public void register(SelectableChannel ch,
                     int interestOps,
                     io.netty.channel.nio.NioTask<?> task)
        Registers an arbitrary SelectableChannel, not necessarily created by Netty, to the Selector of this event loop. Once the specified SelectableChannel is registered, the specified task will be executed by this event loop when the SelectableChannel is ready.

      • getIoRatio

        public int getIoRatio()
        Returns the percentage of the desired amount of time spent for I/O in the event loop.

      • setIoRatio

        public void setIoRatio(int ioRatio)
        Sets the percentage of the desired amount of time spent for I/O in the event loop. The default value is 50, which means the event loop will try to spend the same amount of time for I/O as for non-I/O tasks.

      • rebuildSelector

        public void rebuildSelector()
        Replaces the current Selector of this event loop with newly created Selectors to work around the infamous epoll 100% CPU bug.

      • run

        protected void run()
        Specified by:
        run in class io.netty.util.concurrent.SingleThreadEventExecutor
